paper_metadata.title: A multi-faceted program comprising a grant of productive assets, training, coaching, and savings has been found to build sustainable income for those in extreme poverty

program_information.program_name_citation: Here we explore further results from the Ghana site of Banerjee et al. (2015) : we test whether two of the components, the transfer of a productive asset and the access to savings, are on their own sufficient to generate comparable impacts as the full package.
program_information.country_citation: Here we explore further results from the Ghana site of Banerjee et al. (2015)
program_information.target_population_citation: One of the most exciting ideas in the fight against extreme poverty is the discovery that a focused multifaceted intervention can durably unleash the productive potential of a group of desperately poor people.

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: Here we show that neither transferring a productive asset (in this case, goats) nor providing access to a savings account, on their own, generate similar economically meaningful and sustainable impacts in the same population.

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: This program successfully increased net worth, income and consumption three years after the productive assets were transferred
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Estimates from OLS regressions of household-level economic indices at year two (averaging over two-year outcome and midline outcomes that were collected at least one year after treatment start) on treatments. The omitted group is control households in all villages.
